To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

Ult
o
May
1590
. M
r
Bodeley to my L. from
e
Haghe
.

page.lettertext:
fol.201r
It may please yo
r
L. to be advertised,
at
yo
r
L. letter of
e 23 of this moneth
was brought unto me, uppon
e sealing of my
former:
e contents wherof I will impart to
e states, as yo
r
L. hath required.
The stay of my
L. of Buckehurstes
comming
hither, will be heavy newes to
e most of these
contreis: and for mine owne part, though there
can no service of her
Ma
tie
be unpleasant
unto me, yet unles this government may
be somwhat reformed, I shall finde my service
in this place very weerisome and comfortles.
The very presence of a person of nobilitie,
especially of him whome they desired so muche,
had prevailed greatly w
t
e people of this contrey,
if not thorowly to redresse, w
at
soever is amisse,
yet to reduce it for
e time to a tollerable state.
Whiche I am nowe out of hope to see effected
by any. Astouching
Mons
r
S
t
Al-
degonde
, I am fully persuaded, that he had no
Commission in any thing from
e
General States
,
at his going into
Fraunce
: but was only sent
thither by
e
States of Zelande
. For he had
no sooner founde out
e cipher, and declared
the contents to
e States of Zelande, but they
resolved presently, to send both him and
e letters
to
e
King
. Whiche was all concluded there, w
t
out
e privitie
heere,
ether of
e States, or of
e
Councel
,
Wherat they declared by letters to be muche offended.
It was merveled at by some, that a man of his
qualitie and imploiments, would make suche an
errand, for whiche a letter might have served.
But it was considered againe, that his povertie,
whiche
fol.201v
is thought to be great, and
e smalle reputation
that he lived
in
heere, would cause him to accept of
any thing, that might purchase unto him ether
gaine or grace. And as concerning that motion,
whiche he made unto
e King, I am wholy of beleefe,
that he was not autorised unto it, by
e General
States, or
e States of Zelande, nor
at it came of
himself: but I am rather persuaded, that since his
departure he hath bin written unto by
Count Mau-
rice
and
Barnevelt
, w
t
certaine their adherents,
who make no dout, but if
e King would imbrace
that offer, they would afterwardes finde
e meanes,
that
e generallitie of these Provinces should con-
firme it willingly. I have often adverti-
sed, and it hath bin most apparant by their care-
les courses held w
t
her Ma
tie
that they were
busied in secret, about framing
e modle of some
newe kinde of building. And whether it hath
not bin a principal occasion, that
e autoritie of
the Councel heere could never be established, to
e end a fewe among themselves might have the
maneging of these affaires w
t
out impechement, I
leave to yo
r
L. to consider. To signifie
my conjecture,
e time when Mons
r
S
t
Aldegonde
was made an instrument of this offer, was at
the arrival in Fraunce of
Justinus
Count Mau-
rice basse brother, who was sent expressely to
e
King from Count Maurice, before
e beginning
of this moneth, as
e bruite went, to Congratulat
the victory of
e 4 of Marche, but as it was se-
cretly then spoken, it was chiefly to make an
absolute offer of
e Souveraignetie of these contreis
to
e King, w
t
condition, that Count Maurice might
hold it from him by way of hommage. This
fol.202v
was then
e speeceh among many: but because
I wanted very good autors, I knewe not howe
to credit it: thinking
at, for
e souveraignetie of
e
contrey, they would not be so simple as to move
e Kinge so soone unto it, and so directly
her
against
her Ma
tie
. But it should seeme, they would not
lett slippe
e opportunitie of S
t
Aldegondes being
there: of whose particular affection
at way, they
were well persuaded, and perhaps knewe besides
that his privat state had suche neede, as w
t
promi-
ses and rewardes they might use him to any thing.
And thus muche for part of answear to yo
r
L. letter, hoping in my next, having dealt w
t
e states and
e Councel, to give her Ma
tie
some
further satisfaction.
And so for this present
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
31 May A
o
90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
